Issues.Title: fix(language-service): recognize incomplete pipe bindings with whitespace
Issues.Body:
The Language Service uses the source span of AST nodes to recognize which
node a user has selected, given their cursor position in a template. This is
used to trigger autocompletion.

The previous source span of BindingPipe nodes created a problem when:

1) the pipe binding had no identifier (incomplete or in-progress expression)
2) the user typed trailing whitespace after the pipe character ('|')

For example, the expression `{{foo | }}`. If the cursor preceded the '}' in
that expression, the Language Service was unable to detect that the user was
autocompleting the BindingPipe expression, since the span of the BindingPipe
ended after the '|'.

This commit changes the expression parser to expand the span of BindingPipe
expressions with a missing identifier, to include any trailing whitespace.
This allows the Language Service to correctly recognize this case as
targeting the BindingPipe and complete it successfully. The `nameSpan` of
the BindingPipe is also moved to be right-aligned with the end of any
whitespace present in the pipe binding expression.

This change allows for the disabled test in the Language Service for pipe
completion in this case to be re-enabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(language-service): recognize incomplete pipe bindings with whitespace" (#40346)

Issues.Title: test(core): update test expectation to account for IE11 anonymous function names
Issues.Body:
The "monitoring" workflow has been failing since #40127 was merged,
due to a Saucelabs test failure in Internet Explorer 11. The issue is
with the test's expectation which does not account for Ivy instruction
invocations to use "anonymous" instead of the instruction's function
name. This commit changes the test expectation to also accept
"anonymous", which was already the case for similar expectations.

---

[Failing workflow run for reference](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/angular/26719/workflows/83f00245-fbe4-4aa0-8cca-b859d562623c/jobs/891410)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "test(core): update test expectation to account for IE11 anonymous function names" (#40342)

Issues.Title: queryParms observable always fires empty initially
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/router


### Is this a regression?
No, this has always been an issue.

### Description
I know there have been issues opened for this in the past, e.g. #12157

The Angular team has seemingly decided that this is not a bug, however I, and apparently others, strongly disagree.

Let's just talk about the feature and what one _expects the feature to do_ first:

Per the documentation [here](https://angular.io/api/router/ActivatedRoute#queryParams), the queryParams object on an ActivatedRoute is:

`An observable of the query parameters shared by all the routes.`

This could be taken ambiguously, given that observables are asynchronous constructs. However, and this is the critical point, _as a developer, I expect query string parameters to be available when visiting a route with query string parameters on it, full stop._

When a component first loads, however, queryParams is _always an empty object_, regardless of whether or not there actually are query string params. The problem here is not a simple matter of then subscribing and `.skip(1)`-ing (which in and of itself is a hack, since we _already know we are going to be getting an empty object every single time,_). The important case is the very real, arguably more frequent case where there _are no query string params_, then the queryParams subscription never fires.

Yes, we could just subscribe, but then developers are left open to a race condition with early executing code. An added negative to this approach is that we now have created an open subscription for something that in my experience, 9 times out of 10, we only want once.

The expectation of the developer, if you simply look at the evidence in threads across the internet around this issue, is that `queryParams` gives you the query string parameters of the URL at the time the component is created. I believe this is very hard to argue against, given that this is simply how web development works. The reason I argue this is because if I go to `mysite.com?foo=bar`, I am, before the page has even loaded, specifying query string params - so why in any case ever would I expect the first retrieval of query string params to be empty - let alone _expect_ them to be empty on the first check _every single time_? This leads to literally writing extra "workaround code" everywhere, all the time, to get around a shortcoming - re: bug - in the framework that is of no use and provides no tangible benefit that I've been able to discern.

All arguments that I've read around "it's hard for Angular to know because..." are engineering problems on the Angular side that I strongly believe should be solvable.

Solutions provided (a.k.a. workarounds) include all the way up to manual parsing of the URL itself which defeats a lot of the purpose of having a queryParams observable to begin with.

I'm not going to opine about the technical limitations that I know nothing about within the Angular engine, I am just opening this issue because I find it hard to belive that we cannot make something as integral to web infrastructure as query string parameters available when components are instantiated. The amount of back-bending and weird code required to do something as simple as get qs params on component start up in a non-hacky, non-racey way is kind of surprising. I hate to say this, but I am resorting to manual parsing, or a simple timeout with 10ms on it, which is, yet again, another race condition.

I hope the Angular team is willing to reconsider this, because none of the arguments I've seen against fixing this bug have convinced me that 1) it isn't fixable and 2) there is an actual, valid reason for not doing so.

Thanks!

## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-r7e2ib?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

For repro with qs params in url, go here (this is that stackblitz app):

https://angular-ivy-r7e2ib.stackblitz.io/?foo=bar

## 🌍  Your Environment

This is all versions of angular to my knowledge.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "queryParms observable always fires empty initially" (#40339)

Issues.Title: fix(forms): handle standalone `<form>` tag in `NgControlStatusGroup` directive correctly
Issues.Body:
The `NgControlStatusGroup` directive is shared between template-driven and reactive form modules. In cases when
only reactive forms module is present, the `NgControlStatusGroup` directive is still activated on all `<form>`
elements, but if there is no other reactive directive applied (such as `formGroup`), corresponding `ControlContainer`
token is missing, thus causing exceptions (since `NgControlStatusGroup` directive relies on it to determine the
status). This commit updates the logic to handle the case when no `ControlContainer` is present (effectively making
directive logic a noop in this case).

Alternative approach (more risky) worth considering in the future is to split the `NgControlStatusGroup` into
2 directives with different set of selectors and include them into template-driven and reactive modules separately.
The downside is that these directives might be activated simultaneously on the same element (e.g. `<form>`),
effectively doing the work twice.

Resolves #38391.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(forms): handle standalone `<form>` tag in `NgControlStatusGroup` directive correctly" (#40344)

Issues.Title: fix(router): Remove usage of `Object.entiries` to avoid the need for a polyfill
Issues.Body:
`Object.entries` is not supported in IE11 without a polyfill. The quickest,
most straightfoward fix for this is to simply use `Object.keys` instead.
We may want to consider including the polyfill in the CLI in the future
or just wait until IE11 support is dropped before using
`Object.entires`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(router): Remove usage of `Object.entiries` to avoid the need for a polyfill" (#40340)

Issues.Title: Docs : Confusing messaging around usage & deprecation of entryComponents
Issues.Body:
### Description

It's currently stated that `entryComponents` is deprecated. 

https://angular.io/guide/deprecations#entryComponents

This implies that we shouldn't be using it at all. However, in the documentation for Angular Elements the example illustrates adding a component to `entryComponents` to "exclude it from compilation and avoid startup warnings or errors".

https://angular.io/guide/elements#example-a-popup-service

As far as I'm aware, it's still required to add Angular Elements to `entryComponents` in order to register them, but its deprecation suggests there ought to be another way to do it?

Is that something that needs documenting or is the deprecation warning something that should be ignored?

Either way the messaging here seems confusing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Docs : Confusing messaging around usage & deprecation of entryComponents" (#40341)

Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/forms ### Is this a regression? Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): report non-template diagnostics
Issues.Body:
Report non-template diagnostics when calling `getDiagnostics` function of
the language service we only returned template diagnostics. This change
causes it to return all diagnostics, not just diagnostics from the
template type checker.

Why does this split getDiagnostics into two functions?

A. I split getDiagnostics into two functions. getDiagnostics for getting all diagnostics in the program, and getDiagnosticsForFile, which only gets diagnostics for the argument file. this is because it makes the implementation less complicated, and it aligns with our style guide – better to have two functions that do different things than one function that can do both things.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler-cli): report non-template diagnostics" (#40331)

Issues.Title: @angular-devkit 0.1100.5 > 0.1100.6 breaking change
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 0.1100.5 ### Description This file has a new default value of `true` for `watch`: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/karma/schema.json This breaks `ng test` usual behaviour which previously defaulted to `false` for `watch`, causing tests to hang in the command line when using `ChromeHeadless`. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Create a new angular project using `0.1100.5`, set `karma.conf.js` to `ChromeHeadless` and run `ng test` - the tests will run. Create a new angular project using `0.1100.6`, set `karma.conf.js` to `ChromeHeadless` and run `ng test` - the tests will not run. ## 🔥 Exception or Error Tests will not run. ## 🌍 Your Environment 


Angular CLI: 11.0.6
Node: 14.15.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.0.6
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1100.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1100.6
@angular-devkit/core            11.0.6
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.0.6
@angular/cdk                    11.0.3
@schematics/angular             11.0.6
@schematics/update              0.1100.6
ng-packagr                      11.0.3
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.0.5
**Anything else relevant?** Nope.

Issues.Title: Cannot find module '@angular/cdk/./schematics/migration.json' when updating @angular/material
Issues.Body:
## Description

Hello guys, when I am trying to upgrade my Angular 10 project to Angular 10.

I successfully updated the core and cli packages with:
```ts
ng update @angular/core @angular/cli
```

After trying to update the material package, which updates the cdk package as well, I get the following error:
```ts
ng update @angular/material
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12784974/103762997-def9fc80-5021-11eb-97b4-1ba68b7aa96e.png)

The @angular/cdk folder inside node_modules contains the schematics folder and the migration.json file inside of it, so it seems that the problem might be coming from that **extra "./"** and the path becomes incorrect.

Can you advise on how I can fix this error, so the necessary migrations are executed successfully and the ng update passes?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot find module '@angular/cdk/./schematics/migration.json' when updating @angular/material" (#19726)

Issues.Title: Support custom chunks for webpack / separate chunks for in-house libraries
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->


# 🚀 Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
<!-- ✍️--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
We do most of our component development in an Angular library. That library is linked via package.json (local file reference as it is in a mono-repo style git repository). This library is quite large and it takes time for webpack to re-pack it. The contents get put into `vendor.js` as we have `vendorChunk` set to true. It would be nice to be able to have our library be able to be put in its own chunk file so that the vendor chunk rarely ever changes during a release (it is uncommon for us to change other packages during a release).

While this may be possibly using tools like `@angular-builders/custom-webpack:browser` it would be nice to have greater customization of the chunks that are created via the core builder and angular.json.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ✍️--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
New `additionalChunks` section of angular.json configuration for the `@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser` builder.
It would allow glob matching to customize the chunks.

```
"additionalChunks": {
    "myLib": [ "node_modules/myLib/**" ]
}
```

This would package the "myLib" Angular library as "myLib.[hash].js" in the output of ng build (and a separate file for serve)

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ✍️--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
`@angular-builders/custom-webpack:browser`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support custom chunks for webpack / separate chunks for in-house libraries" (#19721)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-dialog): The typing for `_closeDialogVia` method is invalid
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Try to use `_closeDialogVia` method with a `MatDialogRef<T, R>` where `T` and `R` are different types (probably the most common case).

StackBlitz (really abstract example here, but it shows the behavior):
https://stackblitz.com/edit/dialog-ref-closing-issue?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.ts

#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

TypeScript compiler should allow to use `_closeDialogVia` method with a `MatDialogRef<T, R>` instance where `T` and `R` are different types.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

TypeScript compiler complains about the types of `result` parameter being incompatible with what is provided as an argument.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.1.1
- CDK/Material: 10.2.1
- Browser(s): N/A
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): N/A
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-dialog): The typing for `_closeDialogVia` method is invalid" (#21503)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/a11y): focusVia not accounting for focused child node
Issues.Body:
In #20966 some logic was added so that calling `focusVia` on an element that already has focus would change the origin to the passed-in one. The problem is that the new logic doesn't account for when a parent element is monitored and `focusVia` is called on a child.

These changes add some more logic that will look through all the monitored elements that have `checkChildren: true` and will switch the origin accordingly.

Fixes #21500.

cc @zelliott
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/a11y): focusVia not accounting for focused child node" (#21512)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/table) add directive to enable recycle view repeater
Issues.Body: The CDK and Material tables use the dispose view repeater strategy, which creates new rows from scratch when the dataset changes. This PR adds directives that enable the recycle view repeater, which caches disposed rows and reuses them when the dataset changes. This strategy reduces rendering latency for most tables, but may not be compatible with tables that animate rows.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/table) add directive to enable recycle view repeater" (#21508)

Issues.Title: bug(FocusMonitor): Focus origin of already focused element doesn't change if FocusMonitor is on parent with checkChildren set to true.
Issues.Body:
#### Explanation

The fix https://github.com/angular/components/pull/20966 made it so that the focus origin of an already focused element should change if `focusVia` is called on the element. Unfortunately, this doesn't appear to work if the `FocusMonitor` is on a parent element and set up with `checkChildren = true`. This is because the check here (https://github.com/angular/components/pull/20966/files#diff-02e96e7ea6a7d8f1caecdfdbb7cb38bdcdc5c43db34e4392723cc48765e330b7R316) fails, as `nativeElement` doesn't have a registered `FocusMonitor`. The `FocusMonitor` is instead registered on the parent.

#### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-un8eee?file=src/app/hello.component.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open DevTools and watch the classes on `document.body`. There is a `FocusMonitor` attached to the `document.body`.
1. Click on the button "Focus test button with origin". Note that the class `.cdk-mouse-focused` is first added, and then 5 seconds later, is replaced by the class `.cdk-keyboard-focused`. This is expected behavior. When this button is clicked, it calls `focusVia` wth `keyboard` origin on the "Test" button after 5 seconds.
1. Now, again click on the button "Focus test button with origin". After clicking, and within 5 seconds, click on the button "Test". Now observe that the class `.cdk-mouse-focused` is present, and never changes to `.cdk-keyboard-focused`. **This is not expected behavior.** I'd expect the class to change to `.cdk-keyboard-focused` due to the fix https://github.com/angular/components/pull/20966. Unfortunately it doesn't, because the check `this._elementInfo.has(nativeElement)` fails within `focus-monitor.ts`.

#### Environment

- Angular: Latest
- CDK/Material: Latest
- Browser(s): All
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): All
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(FocusMonitor): Focus origin of already focused element doesn't change if FocusMonitor is on parent with checkChildren set to true." (#21500)

Issues.Title: fix(material/select): NVDA reading out table when opening select on Chrome
Issues.Body:
The `mat-select` trigger element has an `aria-owns` pointing to the overlay and `display: inline-table` in its CSS. The combination of these two causes Chrome to infer the element as a `table` which results in NVDA reading out "table" any time a select is opened.

These changes resolve the issue by setting the element to `role="presentation"`. I've tested out the change against NVDA and VoiceOver and it doesn't seem to affect the accessibility of the select, apart from the "table" not being read out anymore.

Fixes #21480.

For reference, here's what Chrome's constructed a11y node looks like at the moment (note the `LayoutTable`).

![Example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/103535563-9ca5b380-4e99-11eb-8739-3d631cfd5ad3.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/select): NVDA reading out table when opening select on Chrome" (#21492)

Issues.Title: VoiceOver reads out "selected" after each mat-option inside mat-select
Issues.Body: I noticed this after updating to Big Sur and trying out `mat-select` with VoiceOver. While navigating through the list of options, VoiceOver reads out something like "Coffee, selected (5 of 10)" for every single option. My first thought was that it might be due to the fact that we remove `aria-selected` from unselected options in order to reduce noise, but the behavior got even weirder once I got it to set `aria-selected="false"`. Now VoiceOver started reading out both "not selected" and "selected" for each option, e.g. "Coffee not selected, selected (5 of 10)". We'll have to investigate this, because I don't see anything obvious that could be causing it. My best bet is that there's a random "selected" string somewhere in the DOM that is being picked up by VoiceOver.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "VoiceOver reads out "selected" after each mat-option inside mat-select" (#21491)

Issues.Title: feat(google-maps): add heatmap support
Issues.Body:
Adds support for rendering heatmaps on the `google-map` component using the `map-heatmap-layer` directive. The directive is mostly a direct wrapper around the `google.maps.visualization.HeatmapLayer` class, except for the fact that it also accepts a `LatLngLiteral`, whereas the Google Maps class only accepts `LatLng` objects. I decided to add some logic to convert them automatically, because creating `LatLng` requires the Maps API to have been loaded which can lead to race conditions if it's being loaded lazily.

![Example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/103477692-e45d0a00-4dc9-11eb-9f92-6a8f7b2c4614.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(google-maps): add heatmap support" (#21489)
